metadata.title: NBA CBA Study Materials - Batch 13: Article XV - Grievance & Arbitration
metadata.importance: HIGH - Critical for resolving player disputes

studyNote: Article XV establishes the dispute resolution process. Agents must understand how to file grievances, the arbitration process, timelines, and what disputes can be arbitrated.

questions.question: What is a 'grievance' under the CBA?
options: A claim that the CBA, contract, or NBA rules have been violated
questions.explanation: A grievance is a formal claim alleging violation of the CBA, a player contract, NBA Constitution, By-Laws, or other governing rules.

questions.question: Who can file a grievance?
options: Players, teams, or the Players Association
questions.explanation: Grievances can be filed by individual players, teams, or the NBPA on behalf of players or the player body.

questions.question: What is the time limit for filing a grievance?
options: 90 days from when the grievant knew or should have known of the violation
questions.explanation: Grievances must be filed within 90 days of when the party filing knew or reasonably should have known of the act or omission on which the grievance is based.

questions.question: What is the first step in the grievance process?
options: File written grievance with the opposing party
questions.explanation: The grievance process begins with filing a written grievance with the party alleged to have violated the CBA or contract.

questions.question: Who serves as the arbitrator for grievances?
options: Independent arbitrator jointly selected by NBA and NBPA
questions.explanation: An independent arbitrator, jointly selected and paid by the NBA and NBPA, hears and decides grievances.

questions.question: Can players appeal an arbitrator's decision?
options: No, arbitrator decisions are final and binding
questions.explanation: Arbitrator decisions are final and binding on all parties, with very limited grounds for court review (typically only procedural issues).

questions.question: Are there any disputes that cannot be grieved/arbitrated?
options: No, all disputes can be arbitrated
Yes, Commissioner discipline for on-court conduct cannot be arbitrated
Yes, salary disputes cannot be arbitrated
Yes, trade decisions cannot be arbitrated
questions.explanation: The Commissioner's discipline for on-court conduct is explicitly non-arbitrable, though players have limited appeal rights to the Commissioner.

questions.question: Can contract disputes be subject to grievance?
options: Yes, disputes over contract interpretation can be grieved
questions.explanation: Contract interpretation disputes, including issues about guarantees, options, and other terms, can be subject to grievance and arbitration.

questions.question: How long does the arbitrator typically have to issue a decision?
options: As promptly as possible, typically 30-60 days
questions.explanation: The arbitrator must issue decisions as promptly as possible, typically within 30-60 days of the hearing, though complex cases may take longer.

questions.question: Who pays the arbitrator's fees?
options: Split equally by NBA and NBPA
questions.explanation: Arbitrator fees and expenses are split equally between the NBA and NBPA, regardless of the outcome.

questions.question: Can grievance hearings be held during the season?
options: Yes, scheduled around team obligations when possible
questions.explanation: Hearings can be held during the season but are typically scheduled to minimize interference with games and team obligations.

questions.question: Are grievance proceedings confidential?
options: Yes, unless both parties agree to disclosure
questions.explanation: Grievance proceedings are confidential unless both parties agree to make them public. Arbitrator decisions may be disclosed.

questions.question: Can a team grieve a player's conduct?
options: No, only players can file grievances
Yes, teams can file grievances against players
questions.explanation: Teams can file grievances against players for alleged violations of contracts or CBA provisions.

questions.question: What remedies can an arbitrator award?
options: Money damages, contract reformation, specific performance, etc.
questions.explanation: Arbitrators have broad remedial powers including awarding damages, reforming contracts, ordering specific performance, and other appropriate relief.

questions.question: Can multiple grievances be consolidated into one hearing?
options: Yes, if they involve common issues of fact or law
questions.explanation: The arbitrator can consolidate related grievances involving common issues to promote efficiency, even over one party's objection.

questions.question: Are witnesses required to testify at grievance hearings?
questions.explanation: The arbitrator can issue subpoenas requiring witnesses to testify and produce documents for grievance hearings.

questions.question: Can players be represented by attorneys at arbitration?
options: Yes, players can have legal counsel
questions.explanation: Players have the right to be represented by attorneys and/or their agents at all grievance proceedings.

questions.question: What happens if a party fails to comply with an arbitrator's decision?
options: Can be enforced through federal court
questions.explanation: Arbitration awards can be enforced in federal court, and failure to comply can result in court-ordered compliance and additional penalties.

questions.question: Can disputes about draft pick selection be grieved?
options: No, draft decisions are not subject to grievance
questions.explanation: Draft selection decisions by teams are not subject to grievance or arbitration. Teams have sole discretion in their draft choices.

questions.question: What is an 'expedited arbitration'?
options: Faster process for urgent disputes with shortened timelines
questions.explanation: Expedited arbitration is available for urgent matters requiring quick resolution, with shortened filing deadlines and faster hearing schedules.

questions.question: Can the NBPA grieve on behalf of all players (class grievance)?
options: Yes, for systemic violations affecting multiple players
questions.explanation: The NBPA can file class or group grievances on behalf of multiple players when there are systemic CBA violations affecting the player body.

questions.question: Are there any monetary limits on arbitration awards?
options: No limits, arbitrator can award full damages proven
questions.explanation: There are no monetary limits on arbitration awards. The arbitrator can award whatever damages are proven and appropriate under the circumstances.

questions.question: Can a player withdraw a grievance after filing?
options: Yes, at any time before decision
questions.explanation: The party filing a grievance can withdraw it at any time before the arbitrator issues a decision.

questions.question: What standard of proof applies in arbitration?
options: Preponderance of evidence (more likely than not)
questions.explanation: The standard is preponderance of the evidence - the party with the burden must prove their case is more likely true than not.

questions.question: Can settlement discussions be used as evidence in arbitration?
options: No, settlement negotiations are confidential and inadmissible
questions.explanation: Settlement negotiations and offers are confidential and cannot be used as evidence in the arbitration hearing to encourage good faith settlement efforts.
